;区域关注度的提高可能会给菲律宾与越南关系带来一线希望分析人士表示，中国在南海的侵略性活动是因为两国面临的共同威胁使两国更加紧密地联系在一起。

;

;但在这两个东南亚国家之间的海上安全合作得到加强之前，他们专家表示，双方迫切需要找到共同点来处理两国对这条资源丰富的水道的重叠主张。

;

;本月，中国海岸警卫队船只拦截并向执行补给任务的菲律宾船只发射水炮，紧张局势加剧。部队部署在有争议的南沙群岛的 BRP Sierra Madre 船上。

;

;为什么一艘生锈的菲律宾旧军舰卷入南海争端？

;

;马尼拉发动了第二次世界大战- 1990 年代末，一艘时代船在此搁浅，以帮助维护菲律宾主权。

;

;在最近的水炮事件之后，小费迪南德·马科斯 (Ferdinand Marcos Jnr) 总统谈到了菲律宾与越南不断发展的关系的重要性，他表示，合作对于两国关系来说将是“非常大的一步”。

;

;“现在我们要开始讨论菲律宾和越南之间达成的协议，我认为这是非常重要的一步”根据总统通讯办公室的一份声明，马科斯表示：“这是我们关系的重要组成部分，这将为我们目前在南海遇到的问题带来稳定的因素。”在中国日益自信的情况下，两国寻求加强关系，他们必须应对历史上阻碍两国关系的战略挑战，特别是在前总统罗德里戈·杜特尔特(Rodrigo Duterte)上任后，他主张马尼拉在2016-2022年任期内与北京建立更密切的关系，远离华盛顿。

;

;2017年越南渔民与菲律宾海军之间的暴力冲突无助于两国关系，而且在杜特尔特领导下的菲律宾外交政策发生彻底改变的情况下，之前谈判取得的进展似乎也陷入了停滞。 .

;

;越南和菲律宾是直接卷入南海争端的几个东南亚国家之一，它们拒绝北京对南海约 90% 航道的“九段线”主张。

;< p>;这条线实际上由 9 条长划线组成，1953 年首次出现在中国地图上，其基础是国民党 1947 年发布的带有 11 条划线的地图。

;

;中国长期以来一直声称，它对有争议的浅滩和其他海域特征的领土主张——基于所谓的历史性权利——使其能够划出直线基线，建立广阔的沿海管辖权。

;

;东南亚声索国，尽管内部存在分歧共同立场是，海事主张必须以 1982 年《联合国海洋法公约》（Unclos）为基础，该公约由 150 多个国家签署。中国（本身就是签署国）所提出的主张并不符合该公约。

;

;自上任以来，马科斯对北京采取了更强硬的立场，重新点燃与越南的关系似乎是其更大战略的一部分不仅依靠西方与中国打交道，还与周边国家合作。

;

;菲律宾参议院两党支持加强对华政策的原因是什么？

;

;经过多次会议在马科斯与越南总理范明正之间，两国于5月在越南举行了海洋和海洋问题高级别联合常设工作组第十次会议，以深化双边合作。

;

;“[马科斯]政府对南海的政策不再是关于中国将如何应对菲律宾将要做的事情，”新加坡尤索夫伊萨东南亚研究所访问学者阿里斯·阿鲁盖 (Aries Arugay) 表示。

;<他说：“在上届政府的领导下，菲律宾似乎如履薄冰，没有做任何会激怒中国的事情。” “但我们可以看到，在新政府的领导下，这艘船已经起航了。”

;

;虽然越南认为现任马尼拉政府比杜特尔特政府更值得信赖，但从战略上讲，它可能会在其政策上保持更加谨慎和克制。胡志明市社会科学与人文大学讲师 Huynh Tam Sang 表示，“尽管菲律宾和越南加强了关系，共同应对南中国海的海洋问题” ，越南与中国有着紧密的意识形态联系，这两个邻国的全面战略伙伴关系也根深蒂固。

;

;“在大国政治方面采取‘平衡’立场可能会阻碍越南有效与中国交往的具体努力。 Huynh 补充道，如果活动和政策不直接针对中国，越南可能更倾向于与马尼拉合作。

;

;在菲律宾方面，一些立法者可能会认为越南” ，东盟内部国家间关系的开展在很大程度上以务实主义为基础，”他补充道。

;

;阿鲁盖表示，虽然南中国海的类似目标可能会超越意识形态差异，更大的问题在于菲律宾和越南是否能够接受各自的主张。

;

;5月，越南批评一艘中国科考船和一艘菲律宾海岸警卫队船只分别采取行动河内称这侵犯了该国的主权。

;

;“事实是，他们的一些主张仍然重叠，”阿鲁盖说。 “这种进一步的合作实际上可以缓和两国之间的一些问题，这些问题过去可能阻碍两国进行更深入的合作。”

;

;菲律宾是否曾同意移走其搁浅的南海军舰？

;

;菲律宾是否曾同意移走其搁浅的南海军舰？ h3>;

;Huynh 对此表示同意，并表示如果两国有意合作，缩小分歧范围至关重要。

;

;“合作领域包括联合巡逻、军事工业伙伴关系、海岸警卫队的协调可能对双方都有好处。”他说。

;

;越南和菲律宾之间事实上的联盟也可能在挑战北京在南中国海日益增长的足迹方面发挥很大作用。

;

;“在与中国就行为问题进行谈判时，东盟需要有更好的团结，为此，首先需要解决东盟内部在南海的争端，”RSIS 的 Koh 说。

;

;“分裂的东盟对中国来说总是一件好事，因为这使得成员国很难在这些问题上联合起来反对北京。”

;周六，尼日尔自封的军事领导人提议在三年内恢复民主。

;

;上个月政变的领导人阿布拉哈马内·蒂尼将军表示，他已给政府 30 天的时间来确定过渡后恢复民主的框架，过渡期“不能超过三年”。

;

;事态的发展是在西非区域集团仍然希望通过外交手段解决尼日尔危机的同时表示，如果谈判失败，它随时准备动用武力推翻 7 月 26 日的政变。

;

;西非国家经济共同体 (Ecowas) 的一个代表团于周六抵达尼日尔，会见该国军事领导人并驱逐了总统穆罕默德·巴祖姆。

;

;凯瑟琳·菲茨吉本斯 (Kathleen Fitzgibbons) 已抵达尼亚美，领导美国驻尼日尔代表团。美国国务院周六表示，尼日尔。菲茨吉本斯是一位在非洲拥有丰富经验的职业外交官，他将“在这个关键时刻加大力度帮助解决政治危机。”

;

;总统卫队队长蒂亚尼领导的士兵于 7 月夺取政权，并于劫持巴祖姆为人质。他与家人和政府成员一起仍被拘留。西非经共体对士兵采取了强硬立场，关闭边界、实施严厉制裁并启动待命部队。

;

;代表该集团成员国的高级军官阿卜杜勒-法塔乌·穆萨赫 (Abdel-Fatau Musah) 已完成了进入尼日尔的计划该经济组织负责政治事务、和平与安全的专员周五在加纳首都阿克拉举行会议后表示。

;

;军政府及其盟友、邻国马里和布基纳法索 — — 这两个国家都处于军事管辖之下规则 - 正在准备应对可能的军事干预。

;

;“如果发生袭击，我们的领导人已表示我们已做好准备。我们准备支持尼日尔，”布基纳法索国防部长卡苏姆·库利巴利在阿克拉军事首脑会议后告诉俄罗斯国有通讯社 RIA。

;

;尼日尔政变对中国在中东的存在意味着什么萨赫勒地区

;

;

;

;军政府任命的总理阿里·拉明·扎伊纳 (Ali Lamine Zeine) 告诉《纽约时报》，政变领导人无意与克里姆林宫支持的瓦格纳雇佣军组织合作，也无意伤害被废黜的总统.

;

;尼日尔一直是西方的重要盟友，也是世界上最动荡地区之一的相对稳定堡垒。美国在该国设有军用无人机基地，法国驻有约 1,500 名士兵，与尼日尔军队合作，打击与基地组织和伊斯兰国有关联的叛乱分子。

;

;这个内陆国家的两倍多法国幅员辽阔，位居最不发达国家之列。它拥有超过 2500 万人口，是世界上出生率最高的国家之一。

;

;

;

;尼日尔被罢黜的总统穆罕默德·巴祖姆于周六会见了地区调解员，这是与政府的第二次会面。自从上个月军方拘留他以来，他一直是外国代表团的成员。

;

;据总统特别顾问称，巴祖姆在尼日尔首都尼亚美会见了西非经共体代表团。

;

;军政府分享了巴祖姆在会议上。这是自上个月政变以来他第二次被释放。

;

;该地区集团表示，仍希望通过外交手段解决尼日尔危机。但代表团表示，如果谈判失败，它随时准备动用武力推翻 7 月 26 日的政变。

;

;军政府此前曾威胁要以叛国罪起诉巴祖姆，这一罪行可判处死刑。

;中国公园里的孩子们已经从喂养真正的猴子升级到向猴子提供香蕉穿着美猴王服装的人，美猴王是 16 世纪经典小说《西游记》中的角色。

;

;美猴王角色通过人工山上的一个洞吃孩子们喂的食物的视频片段8月16日，中国北部河北省的一个公园在网上疯传。

;

;扮演这个角色的男子（在中国民间传说中也被广泛称为孙悟空）姓于，是一名全职表演者。

;

; p>;

;视频中，他正在表演小说中的一段话，孙悟空被埋在五行山下五百年，这是佛祖反叛上天后，将自己挤进五行山洞里的惩罚。

;

;几个孩子被他的困境所感动，向余提供了饼干、薯片、方便面等物品，最常见的是香蕉——这些在人们的刻板印象中被认为是猴子最喜欢的食物。

;

;“我饿了。太好吃了。”余老师生动地模仿了 20 世纪 80 年代根据小说改编的电视剧《西游记》中孙悟空的语气，对孩子们说道。

;

;这部小说是吴承恩在明朝（1368 - 1644），被视为中国文学四大名著之一。

;

;这部神话冒险故事讲述了唐代高僧玄奘从帝国的朝圣之旅的传奇故事。京城长安，即今西安市，向西包括印度和中亚求取佛经。

;

;孙悟空、半人半猪朱三弟子为伴八戒、沙兽沙悟净、玄奘在旅途中经历了种种磨难。

;

;小说在内地、香港乃至日本等地被改编成多部电视剧和电影。韩国。

;

;1986年拍摄的电视剧《西游记》是该小说最早的电视改编。

;

;改编中，京剧演员刘扮演的孙悟空角色小灵通为当今中国公园和旅游景点常见的业余孙悟空表演者树立了标准。

;

;一些表演者因在强迫游客付费之前诱骗游客拍照而臭名昭著。

;

;余则表示，他演这个角色只是为了弘扬西游文化。

;

;这位前军人演这个角色已经很多年了，除了在公园里演戏外，他还还在街头、商业活动和直播中表演了《真假美猴王》等其他章节。

;

;“干得好，免费吃住，”一位在线观察者说道.

;

;“现在很少有一份工作能有如此多的幸福感了”，另一位网友说道。

;

;“吃饱了，说不定有一天他就能扮演朱八戒，”第三个打趣道。

;香港不断上升的气温促使人们呼吁改善该市监狱的通风但活动人士和立法会议员在为囚犯提供空调问题上仍存在分歧。

;

;前民主党议员刘慧卿和反对派活动人士黄浩明上周敦促惩教署改善通风和降温安排刘还建议安装空调，这一想法被前保安局长黎栋国否决，他告诉《华盛顿邮报》：“监狱不会有空调。这是常识，也是我们的共同理解。”

;

;但是，定期探访监狱检查条件并收集囚犯投诉的太平绅士刘解释了她对高温的担忧，她说：“这不是不是放松，而是人权——生存权和健康权。”

;

;她说，以前天气不那么热的时候，她不建议开空调，但现在天气越来越热了。现在天气非常热，一些囚犯称一整天都浑身出汗。

;

;香港天文台警告说，8 月至 10 月气温将出现“长期显着上升趋势”。早些时候预测，今年夏天可能是有记录以来最热的10个夏天之一。

;

;去年，该市有52个“酷热天”，最高气温达到33摄氏度（91.4华氏度）或更高，创下有记录以来第二高的年度总数。香港今年前 7 个月出现了 29 个“酷热天”。

;

;在美国南部，高温和囚犯因高温而死亡，导致囚犯家属和监狱维权人士受到影响呼吁在监狱安装空调。

;

;《德克萨斯论坛报》报道称，从 6 月中旬到中旬，在没有空调的监狱里，室外温度超过 37.8 度的日子里，至少有 9 名囚犯因心脏病发作或心脏病死亡。今年七月。该州 100 所监狱中的大多数都装有部分空调或没有空调。

;

;“监狱里的生活更好”：生活成本上涨对香港穷人造成沉重打击

;

;莎伦·多洛维奇 (Sharon Dolovich)，来自香港的法学教授加州大学洛杉矶分校及其监狱法律和政策项目主任告诉《华盛顿邮报》，监狱当局应该考虑使用空调，以在气候变化的情况下提供人道的惩教环境。

;

;她不同意提供身体舒适感关在监狱里会降低威慑作用，并表示没有证据表明罪犯在犯罪时考虑了监狱的条件。

;

;最终，她说，剥夺自由和驱逐出社会是“一种极其有害的行为”。

;

;目前尚无香港囚犯因高温死亡的报道，但刘和近年来入狱并探视囚犯的活动人士表示，香港监狱当局可以采取措施更多。

;

;他们说，囚犯们不得不忍受酷热的折磨，而老旧的监狱建筑通风不良，冷却措施不足，情况更加糟糕。

;

;惩教署表示，他们已经安装了风扇，并允许其使用。惩教署发言人在回复刘的来信时表示，自2020年以来，惩教署已在所有29个惩教设施中添加或更换了2,300个风扇，并安装了更多风扇。超过15,000个电风扇，并在牢房内放置超过1,600个具有防自杀设计的滚轴风扇。

;

;并于2018年开始对赤柱监狱进行门窗改造，以改善通风，更换了300扇门和1,000扇窗户，

;

;发言人表示，其他措施包括为建筑物使用耐热涂料，以及在合适的屋顶安装太阳能电池板或植物。

;

;现时的前召集人陈浩焕-解散的民间人权阵线因与2019年香港社会骚乱有关的罪行被判入狱22个月，他回忆说，夏天他在荔枝角接待中心时，出现了痱子，并在半夜醒来。

;

;“我的手臂、身体、大腿内侧，甚至背上都出现了痱子。这真的很艰难，”他说。 “你无法振作起来写信，你无法阅读，光坐在那里就会出汗。”

;

;监狱访客“威胁”接受调查：香港保安局长

;

;当他被转移到石壁监狱时，条件稍微好一些，而且是在宿舍里，而不是被关在单人牢房里。

;

;他敦促当局至少考虑为他们提供凉水。囚犯，因为他在监狱里时只有热水或茶。

;

;社会民主党联盟前主席拉斐尔·黄（Raphael Wong）因与抗议相关的罪行而入狱四次，他同意通风设备宿舍里是可以接受的。

;

; Sun, 20 Aug 2023 07:50:02 +0800 Why China is still on the sidelines in Afghanistan, 2 years after messy US troop pull-outhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3231577/why-china-still-sidelines-afghanistan-2-years-after-messy-us-troop-pull-out?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.08.20 06:00;
;;

;The withdrawal of US troops from Afghanistan in the summer of 2021 continues to be seen as a “black mark” on Joe Biden's presidency – a chaotic and deadly exit that left the war-torn country in a security vacuum as the Taliban swiftly advanced on Kabul.

;

;Two years on, Afghans are still struggling under one of the world's worst humanitarian crises, with most international aid, including from the United States, suspended following the Taliban takeover.

;

;But no major power, not even neighbouring China, appears keen to fill the void that Washington left after its nearly 20-year troop deployment sparked by the September 11 terror attacks.

;

;Afghanistan's severe food insecurity, bleak security and economic situation, and the Taliban's repressive policies against women and girls indicate that the strategic fallout from the messy end to the US military presence could be felt for many years to come, pundits said.

;

;Despite being widely criticised over the US and Nato pull-out, Biden had remained defiant, defending the end of the “longest war in American history” as an “extraordinary success”, and claiming the Afghan exit would help the US focus its energies on the strategic rivalry with China.

;

;“There's nothing China or Russia would rather have, would want more in this competition than the United States to be bogged down another decade in Afghanistan,” Biden said on August 31, 2021, in a statement marking the end of the evacuation operation.

;

;China has made no secret of its joy at America's Afghan debacle and what it calls the failure of US hegemony. It repeated those sentiments on Tuesday – the two-year anniversary of the Taliban takeover of Kabul.

;

;Washington had yet to learn “profound lessons” from the “Kabul moment” of its botched withdrawal, Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Wang Wenbin said.

;

;“The event left behind profound lessons which, to this day, are still worth deep thought,” he said.

;

;“What happened in Afghanistan marked a military, political and counterterrorism failure of the US, and once again proved that military intervention, political infiltration and 'democratic transformation' from the outside will not work and will only breed turmoil and disaster.”

;

;In an apparent jab at the Biden administration, Wang added: “Over the past two years, a certain country has cut off aid, frozen Afghanistan's assets and imposed sanctions, worsening the suffering of the Afghan people.”

;

;Washington has hit back at such characterisation. A Pentagon report last year accused Beijing of trying to “erode US and partner influence” in Afghanistan by highlighting the withdrawal as “evidence that the US is an unreliable partner and declining power”.

;

;However, a US State Department review released last month was deeply critical of the way the evacuation was handled, saying decisions made by Biden and his predecessor Donald Trump had “had serious consequences for the viability” and security of the former US-backed Afghan government.

;

;The Biden administration has played down the criticism, insisting it learned lessons that were later applied in managing the Russian invasion of Ukraine and other crises.

;

;Jennifer Murtazashvili, a non-resident scholar in the Asia Programme at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said the US had suffered “a very serious hit” to its credibility in the region, and it was too early to claim that the lessons from the Afghan exit had been learned.

;

;“The US has not had the time to take stock and learn lessons from Afghanistan,” Murtazashvili said. “This is because the same administration that facilitated the disastrous withdrawal remains in power today.”

;

;'Dark future': Afghanistan's Taliban government marks 2 years in power

;

;Sourabh Gupta, a senior policy specialist with the Institute for China-America Studies in Washington, said the chaotic withdrawal was a black mark on the Biden presidency.

;

;“The chaotic images of desperate Afghans fleeing alongside the US military transport plane at Kabul airport will linger in the collective memory, much like images of the helicopter evacuation from the rooftop of the US embassy in Saigon in 1975,” Gupta said.

;

;But he questioned the claims about a lasting negative impact on American credibility and global standing.

;

;“Just as the 'Saigon moment' of 1975 had few long-lasting ramifications for the credibility of US deterrent power and commitment in the Asia-Pacific – let alone beyond the region, so also the 'Kabul moment' will have even fewer reverberations in external theatres beyond Southwest Asia,” Gupta said.

;

;Wang Duanyong, a research fellow at the Shanghai International Studies University specialising in China's overseas interests, said the end of the US deployment in Afghanistan represented another failed attempt to promote modernisation and political change.

;

;“Afghanistan's recent history of nearly 300 years has seen many attempts at modernisation by internal and external forces, all of which have ended in failure. While this is a failure of the US and other external forces, it is more a failure of Afghanistan and its people,” he said.

;

;However, it would be a mistake to underestimate the lingering influence of the US, Wang – who has made five lengthy field trips to Afghanistan since 2021 – said.

;

;The US is still the largest donor to Afghanistan and has a strong presence on the ground and, despite the Taliban's much-touted anti-American posturing, the regime had been careful to strike a balance between ties with China and the US, he said.

;

;“The Taliban initially tried to win strong support from China and Russia when it came back to power, trying to break its diplomatic isolation. But after it resigned itself to the reality of not being recognised by the international community, ties with China cooled and the Taliban instead sought to increase contacts with the US, in a show of diplomatic flexibility.”

;

;The humanitarian crisis facing Afghanistan was essentially an economic crisis, Wang said. It had been caused mostly by a prolonged period of lack of development, the Taliban's regressive attitude to women's rights, its over-reliance on overseas assistance and the inability to produce an economic reconstruction plan.

;

;Sadiq Amini, a programme manager at Observer Research Foundation America who oversees external relations and outreach, described the chaos of the US withdrawal and the Taliban's reinstatement as a “collective failure” of Washington and other powers.

;

;“This is partially on the US, majorly on Afghans themselves, but more on the regional countries including China, Russia, Iran, Pakistan and others who needed to care enough, and be capable enough to plan, allocate resources, and support Afghanistan post-US withdrawal,” Amini said.

;

;“As a result of their collective failure, the immediate consequences and threats emanating from Afghanistan today, or in the future, are posed against the countries in the region.”

;

;Then a political assistant at the US embassy in Kabul, Amini had helped coordinate the month-long evacuations two years ago. He voiced concerns about the “highly fragile” political, security, and economic situation in Afghanistan.

;

;Following the Taliban takeover, external powers including the US, China, Pakistan, Iran, Russia and India had only “minimal influence” in Afghanistan, and that too was “tactical, short-term, and transactional in nature”, Amini said.

;

;“It definitely is not serving Afghanistan.”

;

;Amini was particularly critical of China's ties with the Taliban and its cautious, wait-and-see approach in post-war Afghanistan, with a primary focus on countering Islamic extremism and ensuring stability on its western border.

;

;Diplomatic overtures to the Taliban “will not lead to influence”, he said. “Rather, it will lead to resentment against China, which is already showing among the people of Afghanistan, who see China warmly engaging the Taliban with no vision to serve Afghans in the long-term.”

;

;Short of a formal recognition, China was among the first countries to welcome the Taliban's return to power and one of only a handful to host a Taliban charge d'affaires.

;

;Wang Yi, now China's foreign policy chief, became the first foreign minister of any country to meet the new Taliban rulers in Kabul when he travelled there in March last year.

;

;In contrast, Beijing had appeared more cautious in its dealings with the hardline militant group during the Taliban's first takeover in 1996, refusing to recognise it and shutting all crossings along their 92km (57-mile) border.

;

;Amini argued that considering the doubts over the Taliban's willingness or ability to prevent terrorism from spilling over to neighbouring countries, Beijing should reach out to non-Taliban Afghans, the US and regional countries to collectively address the Afghan crisis.

;

;Other observers were less optimistic about China's future role.

;

;Andrew Small, a senior transatlantic fellow with the German Marshall Fund's Indo-Pacific Programme, said Afghanistan in the aftermath of a US withdrawal was always seen as “more of a trap than an opportunity” for China.

;

;“And the Chinese government has been careful not to fall into it,” he said.

;

;“The risk is that deeper involvement looks easy during periods of calm and then turns into a liability when the situation turns and when resentment about foreign presence grows.”

;

;China was under no illusions about great influence over the Taliban, Small said.

;

;“[China] have dealt with them for over two decades, and even if they hoped for a more pragmatic approach in government, they are aware of the Taliban's ideological nature,” he said. “There is modest scope for expanding their commercial footprint in Afghanistan, but only at a level that doesn't turn into significant risks or liabilities.”

;

;Small also said China's ties with the US over Afghanistan did not have “the depth of cooperation that was there in the past”. But the two sides still had relatively similar objectives there, so “it isn't likely to be a major area of Sino-US contention either.”

;

;China and the US used to cooperate during the 2010s on various capacity-building initiatives in Afghanistan, including police training and demining activities.

;

;Yun Sun, China programme director and co-director of the East Asia programme at the Stimson Centre in Washington, Afghanistan was no longer the centre of geopolitical sparring.

;

;For Beijing, the situation there is not as bad as might have been expected two years ago, Sun said, though “at this point, Afghanistan is still more a challenge than an opportunity for China”.

;

;“The large exodus of refugees or inflow of militants into China did not happen. No major power has shown any interest in filling the vacuum in Afghanistan,” she said. “China is not willing to take on such a big burden and risk by itself, which is why it has organised a regional multilateral platform- the Foreign Ministers' Meeting of Afghanistan's Neighbours- to develop a collective approach.”

;

;Murtazashvili also said the Afghanistan factor was unlikely to figure in the US-China relationship going forward, despite a shared interest in rooting out terrorism.

;

;China had become a much more significant target for terrorists in Afghanistan than American interests, she said. “The US left Afghanistan with its tail between its legs, humiliated. China seems to be the next great power with interests in Afghanistan – so it has become a target for opponents of the Taliban.”

;

;Chinese investments in Afghanistan have been targeted by Islamic State-affiliates and other terror outfits. At least five Chinese nationals were seriously injured in December when an Isis affiliate attacked a hotel in downtown Kabul catering to Chinese businesspeople.

;

;Murtazashvili said while the Taliban had on the one hand failed to ensure the promised internal security and stability, the regime's reticence over Beijing's suppression of its ethnic minority Uygur population in exchange for economic support had also backfired.

;

;“The treatment of the Uygurs has been a quiet rallying call for groups like Islamic State who are able to point out what they believe to be the hypocrisy of the Taliban who seem to have quite close relations with the Chinese government regardless.”

;

;Wang at the Shanghai International Studies University also said that China's biggest problem in Afghanistan was a lack of security guarantees.

;

;Beijing and its embassy in Kabul have repeatedly warned of the risks of investing in Afghanistan at this stage.

;

;“With Afghan trade accounting for only about one ten-thousandth of China's foreign trade, Afghanistan is of limited significance for China, especially economically,” he said.

;“I don't think any of us – I know me particularly – never thought I'd be standing here talking about a hurricane or a tropical storm,” said Janice Hahn, chair of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors.

;Forecasters said the storm could bring heavy rainfall to the southwestern United States, dumping 8cm to 15cm in places, with isolated amounts of up to 25cm, in portions of southern California and southern Nevada.

;

;The US National Hurricane Centre issued tropical storm and potential flood warnings for Southern California from the Pacific coast to interior mountains and deserts. The San Bernardino County sheriff on Saturday issued evacuation warnings for several mountain and foothill communities ahead of the storm.

;

;“This is being labelled as historic, life-threatening and potentially catastrophic rainfall for Southern California and a good chunk of the desert Southwest in general”, said John Cangialosi, a senior hurricane specialist at the National Hurricane Centre. “That is because we could see about a year's worth of rain from this event for those regions”.

;

;Heatwave triggers big storms, power cuts in US Southeast, raises wildfire concerns

;

;Courtney Carpenter, a National Weather Service warning coordination meteorologist, said experts forecast flash floods, mudslides, isolated tornadoes and wind damage to Southern California, as well as life-threatening surf conditions and rip currents to the beaches.

;

;Heavy rainfall and strong winds began Saturday, and power outages are expected.

;

;Hilary rapidly gained strength on Friday, becoming an exceedingly dangerous Category 4 Major hurricane with top sustained winds of 230kp/h at its peak. And though its maximum sustained winds dropped to 115mph 185kp/h on Saturday, it still was a very dangerous Major Category 3 storm.

;

;By midday Saturday, the storm was centred about 570km south-southeast of Punta Eugenia, one of the westernmost spurs on Mexico's southern Baja peninsula. ;

;

;President Joe Biden said on Friday the Federal Emergency Management Agency had pre-positioned staff and supplies in the region. “I urge everyone, everyone in the path of this storm, to take precautions and listen to the guidance of state and local officials,” he said.

;

;Officials in Southern California were re-enforcing sand berms, built to protect low-lying coastal communities against winter surf, like in Huntington Beach, which dubs itself as “Surf City USA.”

;

;In nearby Newport Beach, Tanner Atkinson waited in a line of vehicles for free sandbags at a city distribution point.

;

;“I mean a lot of people here are excited because the waves are gonna get pretty heavy”, Atkinson said. “But I mean, it's gonna be some rain, so usually there's some flooding and the landslides and things like that”.

;

;About 100 people sought refuge at storm shelters in the twin resorts of Los Cabos, at the southern tip of the Baja peninsula, and firefighters used an inflatable boat to rescue a family in San Jose del Cabo after the resort was hit by driving rain and wind.

;

;In La Paz, the picturesque capital of Baja California Sur state on the Sea of Cortez, police patrolled closed beaches to keep swimmers out of the whipped-up surf.

;Zimbabwe's election looks to be over before it's even started.

;

;A deeply divided opposition, hobbled by a slew of court cases, has struggled to capitalise on public outrage about the near-collapse of government services, triple-digit inflation and rampant poverty. That's put octogenarian President Emmerson Mnangagwa in pole position to win the August 23 vote.

;

;The integrity of the contest has been called into question, with Amnesty International accusing the government of undermining civil liberties over the past five years, helping entrench the incumbent's dominance. The watchdog also criticised Zimbabwe's so-called Patriotic Bill that came into force last month and makes it illegal to wilfully injure the nation's sovereignty and national interests, saying it further criminalises dissent.

;

;“The odds are stacked against the opposition,” the Institute for Security Studies, a Pretoria-based think tank, said in a research note. The government has “weaponised the law,” used nonviolent coercion to intimidate people into supporting it and taken credit for government-funded programmes, it said.

;

;China's clean energy demands fuel Zimbabwe's race up the mining value chain

;

;Winning a tainted election may derail efforts by Mnangagwa, who's held power since long-time ruler Robert Mugabe was ousted in a 2017 coup, to restructure the nation's US$18 billion of debt arrears. Creditors including the African Development Bank have warned that any deal would be contingent on a credible contest.

;

;“There would be very little sympathy in terms of debt relief” or other help from the West if the vote is compromised, said Stephen Chan, a professor of world politics at the School of Oriental and African Studies in London.

;

;The government rejected Amnesty's findings and Mnangagwa has pledged that the election will be credible, with 45 nations and 17 continental and regional bodies having been invited to send observers. The Zimbabwe African National Union-Patriotic Front has ruled Zimbabwe since it gained independence from Britain in 1980.

;

;“We are entrenching democracy and constitutionalism, good governance and human rights. No one, no one is qualified to teach us democracy”, the president, told a cheering crowd of tens of thousand of people who attended an election rally in Shurugwi, south of the capital, Harare, on Saturday. “It is us who want free, fair transparent elections. It is us. We are not doing this to please anybody”.

;

;Almost half of 2,400 Zimbabweans polled by pan-African survey company Afrobarometer in April and May said they don't expect the election results to reflect how citizens voted and most anticipate violence after the ballot. An earlier poll of 1,000 voters commissioned by the Johannesburg-based Brenthurst Foundation and conducted by the Sabi Strategy Group, found the opposition Citizens Coalition for Change would win a fair contest.

;

;Tony Hawkins, an economics professor at the University of Zimbabwe, sees the election having little impact on the economy, with Western nations and donors loathe to engage with the government irrespective of the outcome.

;

;“The election is a non-event”, he said. “It's already decided”.

;A shoot-out erupted on Saturday near a restaurant where Ecuadorean presidential candidate Otto Sonnenholzner was eating with his family, police and the candidate said, though the violence was not directed at him.

;

;Ecuadoreans head to the polls on Sunday to elect a new president and legislature after a campaign clouded by the assassination of anti-corruption candidate Fernando Villavicencio 10 days ago.

;

;“We just suffered a shoot-out in front of the place where I was breakfasting with my family”, Sonnenholzner, a pro-market candidate and former vice-president said on X, previously called Twitter. “Thank God we're all well but we demand an investigation into what occurred”.

;

;A video on social media showed Sonnenholzner greeting a supporter in a sunny restaurant in Guayaquil and preparing to take a selfie, before shots sound outside.

;

;The national police said in a press conference the shoot-out was the result of a chase after a robbery in an exercise clothing store and that five people have been arrested.

;

;More Ecuadorean kidnappers cutting off victims' fingers to get hefty ransoms

;

;Sonnenholzner has hardened his discourse around crime since the murder of Villavicencio, repeatedly promising his supporters that should he be elected, criminals who use violence against citizens will be shot by police.

;

;Fellow presidential candidate Daniel Noboa said on Thursday that there was an attack on his campaign caravan in Duran, but police later said the shooting was not directed at Noboa, son of prominent banana businessman and former presidential candidate Alvaro Noboa.

;

;Meanwhile, Francisco Tamariz, the mayor of the coastal city of La Libertad, said on X on Saturday that shots were fired by police on Friday at a truck in which he and his wife were riding.

;

;Police in Santa Elena province said in a press conference three armoured cars without official logos avoided a police stop and officers eventually shot to stop the vehicles.

;

;Three people from one of the cars were arrested and two unlicensed firearms were found, police said.

;

;Tamariz said he would complain to the attorney general's office.

;

;The mayor of the Pacific port city of Manta, Agustin Intriago, was murdered in July. The police said on Friday morning that they detained four people in his killing.
